stems: Higher education includes high schools, colleges and other institutions.
At the end of a university course, students get a degree.
A university faculty is larger than a department.
A discipline is another word for a subject that you study.
A university department usually teachers many different subjects.
data.stimulus:
Lets start with two short reading tasks.

► Are the sentences below True or False?

Next, read the short texts below about university students talking about their studies.

► Complete the summaries with a word from the drop down.
data.template:
Rebecca studies {{response}} in {{response}}, Yasuko studies {{response}} in {{response}} and Dipak studies {{response}} in {{response}}.
{{response}} knows lots of international students.

data.stimulus: ► Complete the sentences about the three students using the words below (drag and drop).
data.template:
Rebecca is a  {{response}} in Oxford. She's in her second year at the moment.
She's doing a {{response}} in medicine and hopes to become a doctor when she finishes.
Yasuko is {{response}} law, in particular international law.
She's at {{response}} in Melbourne, Australia.
Dipak is an {{response}} doing a course in engineering in London.

data.stimulus:
Let's focus on Vocabulary

► Consider the words below. Drag and drop them onto the table.
► Match the kinds of coursework with their definition.
data.template:
1. A piece of writing that uses a formal style to present and discuss the results of research and provide recommendations based on your findings. {{response}}
  2. A task that your tutors or lecturers set. This can be a writing task (e.g. a report) or a speaking task (e.g. a presentation). {{response}}
  3. The question that your tutor or lecturer wants you to work on. This includes all the details of your assignment (e.g the topic, the format, the word count, the due date). {{response}}
  4. A collection of individual pieces of work completed by a student over a longer period of time. {{response}}
  5. A speaking assignment that must be prepared and delivered by more than one student. {{response}}
  6. A longer research-based work (between 10,000 to 15,000 words), which is usually completed at the end of a degree. {{response}}

value: Some reading assignments may be very long.
Most of the reading is done outside class. You are expected to come to class with a basic understanding of the material.
Reviewing for exams is primarily your responsibility.
A large percentage of the score is writing based.
Writing assignments are always based on research.
You may be asked to write different kinds of texts: Reports, proposals, blogs, reflective writing, …
Teachers expect you to be proactive and find your own strategies.

data.stimulus: Let's start by comparing academic writing with writing at secondary school level.
stimulus_list: Some of the reading is done in class.
Teachers often provide study guides to help you prepare for exams.
Your final grade is based on a wide variety of assessments.
Writing assignments include personal writing and creative writing
The kind of writing assignments is generally stable over the high school years.
Teachers will tell you what the best strategies are to complete your assignments.

value: Some reading assignments may be very long.
Most of the reading is done outside class. You are expected to come to class with a basic understanding of the material.
Reviewing for exams is primarily your responsibility.
A large percentage of the score is writing based.
Writing assignments are always based on research.
You may be asked to write different kinds of texts: Reports, proposals, blogs, reflective writing, …
Teachers expect you to be proactive and find your own strategies.

data.stimulus:
Here are some characteristics of Academic Writing.

► Complete the points below by choosing the correct heading from the drop down.
data.template:
Academic writing... 

Note: there is one extra option that you don't need.

... answers a question and demonstrates an understanding of the subject .
This means that academic writing should be {{response}}.

... is coherent, written in a logical order, and brings together related points and material. 
This means that academic writing should be {{response}}.

... supports all opinions and arguments with evidence. 
This means that academic writing should be {{response}}.

... uses appropriate language and tenses, and is clear, concise and balanced. 
This means that academic writing should be {{response}}.

... should make a logical and objective argument. Whether you personally agree or disagree with an idea, it must be presented accurately and objectively in your paper. 
This means that academic writing should be {{response}}.

data.stimulus:
And here are some things you should avoid when writing academic texts.

► Complete the points below by choosing the correct heading from the drop down.
data.template:
Things to avoid: 

Note: there is one option that you don't need.

The goal of academic writing is to express complex ideas in a clear, concise manner. Avoid confusing language and long sentences (as a general rule, no more than 40 words per sentence).
This means that academic writing should NOT be {{response}}.

Academic writing is formal in tone and should not include slang, idioms, or conversational language.
This means that academic writing should NOT be {{response}}.

Academic writing must go beyond the writer’s own ideas. Make sure do your research to find evidence to back your claims.
This means that academic writing should NOT be {{response}}.

Do not just repeat the ideas or arguments from your source materials. Rather, analyse those arguments and explain how they relate to your point.
This means that academic writing should NOT be {{response}}.

list: Read the brief very carefully to understand what you need to do. Think about what you know about the subject and write it down.
Read about the subject to increase your topic knowledge (general websites are fine at this stage only).
Check your reading list (if you have one) and start your research: find relevant books, articles or websites. Make a note of all the materials you use.
Start typing or writing a first draft.
Discuss your first draft with classmates and your lecturer if possible.
Revise your first draft, considering any comments from discussions. Proofread and check your draft.
data.stimulus:
An essential step in writing an academic assignment is to plan your work.

 

 

► Here are some planning suggestions. Organise them in logical order.
f
data.template:
1.  {{response}} (n) The date by which you must finish your assignment.
  2.  {{response}} (n) The initial version of your written assignment. Usually you show this to your tutor or lecturer before you complete the final version.
  3.  {{response}} (n) A diagram that lays out ideas for the topic and shows how they are connected to each other.
  4.  {{response}} (n) Comments from your tutor or lecturer.
  5.  {{response}} (v) Send to your tutor to be marked.
  6.  {{response}} (v) Evaluate and give a final grade.

data.stimulus:
Let's finish this lesson by reviewing the writing process and assessment. 

► Complete each gap with a word from the drop down (there are some extra words that you don't need)
data.template:
The Writing Process:

When planning an assignment, it's a good idea to start with a {{response}} to help you generate ideas. Make sure you finish your {{response}} a few weeks before the {{response}} so that you have time to make changes if necessary.

Assessment:

After the assignment is {{response}} it will be  {{response}} and you will usually receive {{response}} from your tutor or lecturer.
